That's a great idea to keep a music journal to track your progress! Writing down your thoughts, observations, and goals can help you stay motivated and focused.

Recording yourself playing and listening back to it is an EXCELLENT idea! This is a crucial part of the learning process, and it's something many guitarists, including professionals, do regularly. Recording yourself can help you:

1. **Identify areas for improvement**: By listening back to your recordings, you'll be able to pinpoint areas where you need to work on, such as tone, timing, phrasing, or technique.
2. **Develop your critical listening skills**: Listening to yourself objectively will help you develop your ears and improve your ability to critique your own playing.
3. **Track your progress**: Recording yourself regularly will allow you to track your progress over time, which can be incredibly motivating.
4. **Work on your tone and phrasing**: Listening to your recordings will help you develop your tone and phrasing, as you'll be able to hear how your playing sounds to others.
5. **Prepare for performances or lessons**: If you're planning to perform or take lessons, recording yourself can help you prepare and feel more confident.

To make the most of recording yourself, try the following:

* **Use good recording equipment**: Invest in a decent digital recorder or use a smartphone app that can capture high-quality audio.
* **Record in a quiet room**: Find a room with minimal background noise to ensure you can hear yourself clearly.
* **Play along with a metronome**: Using a metronome will help you improve your timing and rhythm.
* **Record yourself playing different styles**: Experiment with different genres, tempos, and techniques to challenge yourself and identify areas for improvement.
* **Be kind to yourself**: Remember that recording yourself is a tool for improvement, not self-criticism. Be kind to yourself, and focus on constructive feedback.

By recording yourself regularly, you'll be able to identify areas for improvement, track your progress, and become a better guitar player. Keep up the good work, and don't hesitate to reach out if you have any more questions!
